The theory that the animal characters in: Winnie-the-Pooh' represent various mental disorders was first popularized in a tongue-in-cheek paper published in 2000, more than 70 years after the first book was released.
The theory was not an expression of the: A. Milne, but rather a later interpretation by a group of modern neurodevelopmentalists.
The humorous tone of the paper and the p: future suggest that the determinations were not meant to be taken seriously.
